title: How the brain responds to reward is linked to socioeconomic background
excerpt: The brain’s sensitivity to rewarding experiences — a critical factor in motivation and attention — can be shaped by socioeconomic conditions, according to an MIT study.

title: Shari Liu: How babies think about danger | TED Talk
excerpt: Are babies oblivious to danger? It's not that simple, says cognitive scientist Shari Liu. Sharing surprising insights (and plenty of baby videos) from studies of early human development, Liu highlights the unexpected ways babies perceive and respond to risky situations — and what these findings could unravel about the inner workings of our minds.

title: How Loneliness Reshapes the Brain | Quanta Magazine
excerpt: Feelings of loneliness prompt changes in the brain that further isolate people from social contact.

title: The Neuroscience Behind Bad Decisions
excerpt: Irrationality may be a consequence of the brain’s ravenous energy needs.

title: Animal Magic: Why Intelligence Isn’t Just for Humans
excerpt: Meet the footballing bees, optimistic pigs and alien-like octopuses that are shaking up how we think about minds.

title: How the Brain Links Gestures, Perception and Meaning
excerpt: Neuroscience has found that gestures are not merely important as tools of expression but as guides of cognition and perception.

title: Why Do We Even Listen to New Music?
excerpt: Our brains reward us for seeking out what we already know. So why should we reach to listen to something we don’t?

title: Does the Rorschach Inkblot Test Really Work?
excerpt: Learn about the Rorschach inkblot test, a type of projective assessment in which subjects look at 10 ambiguous inkblot images and say what they see in the image.

title: Neuroscience may have a part in why you're playing Taylor Swift's songs on
excerpt: Taylor Swift literally has music down to a science

title: How the Brain Responds to Beauty
excerpt: Scientists search for the neural basis of an enigmatic experience
